query:
Write a Related Works section for an academic paper given the paper's abstract. Here is the paper abstract:
Unsupervised domain adaptation for semantic segmentation (UDA-SS) aims to
transfer knowledge from labeled source data to unlabeled target data. However,
traditional UDA-SS methods assume that category settings between source and
target domains are known, which is unrealistic in real-world scenarios. This
leads to performance degradation if private classes exist. To address this
limitation, we propose Universal Domain Adaptation for Semantic Segmentation
(UniDA-SS), achieving robust adaptation even without prior knowledge of
category settings. We define the problem in the UniDA-SS scenario as low
confidence scores of common classes in the target domain, which leads to
confusion with private classes. To solve this problem, we propose UniMAP:
UniDA-SS with Image Matching and Prototype-based Distinction, a novel framework
composed of two key components. First, Domain-Specific Prototype-based
Distinction (DSPD) divides each class into two domain-specific prototypes,
enabling finer separation of domain-specific features and enhancing the
identification of common classes across domains. Second, Target-based Image
Matching (TIM) selects a source image containing the most common-class pixels
based on the target pseudo-label and pairs it in a batch to promote effective
learning of common classes. We also introduce a new UniDA-SS benchmark and
demonstrate through various experiments that UniMAP significantly outperforms
baselines. The code is available at
\href{https://github.com/KU-VGI/UniMAP}{this https URL}.

nuggets.text: Semantic segmentation models are vulnerable to domain and category shifts
Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (UDA) uses labeled source and unlabeled target data
UDA for segmentation: adversarial learning and self-training approaches
UDA requires prior knowledge of class overlap, limiting generalizability
Universal Domain Adaptation (UniDA) addresses unknown category configurations
UniDA is underexplored in semantic segmentation compared to classification
UniDA-SS enables adaptation without prior knowledge of category overlap
UniMAP: UniDA-SS with Image Matching and Prototype-based Distinction
Domain-Specific Prototype-based Distinction (DSPD) separates domain-specific features
Target-based Image Matching (TIM) pairs source and target images for common classes
UniMAP introduces a new UniDA-SS benchmark and outperforms baselines
Semantic segmentation classifies each pixel into a semantic category
Fully Convolutional Networks (FCNs) are foundational for semantic segmentation
Dilated convolutions, global pooling, and pyramid pooling enhance context in segmentation
Attention mechanisms and transformers improve semantic segmentation performance
Adversarial UDA uses domain classifiers for domain-invariant features
Self-training UDA assigns pseudo-labels to target pixels using confidence thresholding
UniDA in classification: confidence-based unknown detection, thresholding methods
CMU, ROS, DANCE, OVANet: thresholding strategies for UniDA in classification
